conclusion: Problem involves a 5m wooden rod falling freely from a fixed point 20m above a cylinder AB.
Need to find the time for the rod to pass through the upper end A of the cylinder.
Wooden rod is hanging from a fixed point and released to fall freely.
Cylinder AB is fixed in space, 20 meters below the suspension point.
Rod is 5 meters long, and cylinder AB is also 5 meters tall.
When the upper end of the rod aligns with the upper end A of the cylinder, the lower end of the rod would be at the same level as the lower end B of the cylinder.
Need to find when the lower end of the rod passes through the upper end A of the cylinder.
Suspension point is 20 meters above the upper end A of the cylinder.
Rod is 5 meters long, hanging from the suspension point.
Upper end of the rod starts at the suspension point, 20 meters above A.
Lower end of the rod starts 5 meters below the suspension point, so at 15 meters above A.
When the upper end of the rod reaches A, the lower end would have fallen the same amount of time, so its position would be 15 meters minus the distance it fell in that time.
Consider positions in terms of distance fallen: upper end needs to fall 20 meters to reach A, lower end needs to fall 15 meters to reach A.
Both ends are falling freely, so their positions at any time t are: upper end position: \( h_u = 20 -  rac{1}{2} g t^2 \), lower end position: \( h_l = 15 -  rac{1}{2} g t^2 \).
Set \( h_l = 0 \) to find when the lower end of the rod passes through A.
